text: [chanting]

MARTIN SAVIDGE: Talat Rashid and
Dr. Waqas Khan faced an anger

and ugliness they'd never seen
before thanks to Donald Trump.

TALAT RASHID: I have
some of my close friends.
They turned their back on me.

MARTIN SAVIDGE:
Pakistani-Americans
and Muslim--

the backlash wasn't
against their faith,
but their politics.

TALAT RASHID: I
supported Donald Trump.

MARTIN SAVIDGE: Rashid
campaigned for Trump,
and twice got to meet him.

Khan and Rashid
even went to Trump's

inauguration, all
of which earned
them scorn from fellow Muslims.

DR. WAQAS KHAN: I had to
receive comments like, oh,
I never knew you were a racist.

You are anti-Islamic,
you are a traitor,

a brown guy trying to be white,
Brownie, all these slurs.

MARTIN SAVIDGE: Trump's
campaign rhetoric,

particularly about Muslims,
bothered many people,
including Saleem Sheikh.

He's friends with Rashid,
attends the same Bolingbrook

mosque, and is a
lifelong Republican
who voted for Hillary Clinton.

SALEEM SHEIKH: I was
quite concerned about some

of Mr. Trump's
statements at that time.

DONALD TRUMP: Total
and complete shutdown

of Muslims entering
the United States,

until our country's
representatives can figure
out what the hell is going on.

MARTIN SAVIDGE: How could
you support a man who
seemed to be so anti-Muslim?

DR. WAQAS KHAN: When the
statement about the Muslim ban

came out, I was kind of
offended, to be very honest.

But then I took a deep breath,
and I looked at the message
behind the statement.

MARTIN SAVIDGE: The
message Rashid and Khan
heard wasn't of discrimination.

Instead, they heard Trump
identifying a problem they see

in their own faith, one they
say American leaders and even

many Muslims up till now
haven't openly faced,
violent, radical extremism.

DR. WAQAS KHAN: The main war
is between, is within Islam,
is not outside Islam.

And the first war
that we have to win

is the war that the reformists,
or the moderate Muslims,

have to win against
the radicals.

MARTIN SAVIDGE:
Terrorism, the men say,
is a byproduct of that war.

And Trump is taking action
against some Muslims
to protect all Americans.

Still, they admit the first
travel ban was a mistake.

TALAT RASHID: Yeah, I
think that was too much.

I mean, I did not agree
with him in the beginning.

MARTIN SAVIDGE: You
think it's better now?

TALAT RASHID: It's
a little better now.

It is, but again you know,
his message is, he is not--

it's not that he's
hating all the Muslims.

He is just trying to
protect this country
as a president, that's his job.

MARTIN SAVIDGE:
Saleem disagrees,

saying the best way
to protect America
is not by shutting people out.

SALEEM SHEIKH: I'm a very
patriotic American citizen.

So I want to look and
see America as being
number one in the world.

But I think it can do that by
reaching out to the people.

MARTIN SAVIDGE: Like many
of Donald Trump supporters,

Rashid and Khan say
that kind of thinking

is too idealistic in
today's frightening world.

DR. WAQAS KHAN: America's
national security

should be beyond
any politics, it
should be beyond any religion.

That should be a top
priority, being an American.
